words.meaning: A deep-seated feeling of dislike; aversion.
examples: He had a strong antipathy towards cats.
There has always been a great deal of antipathy between the two leaders.

words.meaning: The direct opposite of someone or something.
examples: His theory is the antipode of the traditional view.
In personality, she is the antipode of her exuberant sister.

words.meaning: Old-fashioned or outdated.
examples: He has some antiquated ideas about the roles of men and women.
The factory uses antiquated machinery.

words.meaning: Scrupulously clean or pure, especially so as to be bland or characterless.
examples: The hotel room was bland and antiseptic.
His writing style is so antiseptic that it lacks any emotion.

words.meaning: A person or thing that is the direct opposite of someone or something else.
examples: Love is the antithesis of selfishness.
His liberal views are the antithesis of my conservative beliefs.

words.meaning: Directly opposed or contrasted; mutually incompatible.
examples: The two policies are antithetical to each other.
Her actions were antithetical to her stated beliefs.

words.meaning: Swiftly; quickly.
examples: The project is coming along apace.
Technological change continues apace.

words.meaning: A policy or system of segregation or discrimination on grounds of race, notably in South Africa.
examples: Nelson Mandela fought against the injustices of apartheid.
The system of apartheid created deep divisions in society.

words.meaning: Showing or feeling no interest, enthusiasm, or concern.
examples: The voters were apathetic and turnout was low.
He felt too apathetic to even get out of bed.

words.meaning: Lack of interest, enthusiasm, or concern.
examples: Widespread apathy among students is a major problem.
Voter apathy can undermine a democracy.

words.meaning: The top or highest part of something, especially one forming a point.
examples: He reached the apex of his career at the age of 40.
The apex of the mountain was covered in snow.

words.meaning: A pithy observation that contains a general truth.
examples: One of his favorite aphorisms is 'actions speak louder than words.'
The book is a collection of his most famous aphorisms.

words.meaning: Something that is concise and instructive of a general truth or principle.
examples: He had an aphoristic style of writing that was easy to quote.
Her speech was full of aphoristic wisdom.

words.meaning: Self-confidence or assurance, especially when in a demanding situation.
examples: She handled the difficult questions with great aplomb.
The diplomat negotiated the treaty with his usual aplomb.

words.meaning: (of a story or statement) of doubtful authenticity, although widely circulated as being true.
examples: Most of the stories about him are apocryphal.
It's an apocryphal tale, but it makes for a good story.

words.meaning: The highest point in the development of something; a climax or culmination.
examples: The Roman Empire reached its apogee in the 2nd century AD.
His career reached its apogee with the award of the Nobel Prize.

words.meaning: A person who offers an argument in defense of something controversial.
examples: He is a well-known apologist for the company's environmental record.
She became an apologist for the new government policy.

words.meaning: Overcome with anger; extremely indignant.
examples: He was apoplectic with rage at the decision.
The news left her apoplectic.

words.meaning: A person who renounces a religious or political belief or principle.
examples: He was declared an apostate for his heretical views.
The former party leader was denounced as an apostate.

words.meaning: A vigorous and pioneering advocate or supporter of a particular policy, idea, or cause.
examples: He was an apostle of free-market economics.
She is a modern-day apostle for environmentalism.

words.meaning: The highest point in the development of something; culmination or climax.
examples: His appearance at the concert was the apotheosis of his career.
The film is the apotheosis of the classic Western.

words.meaning: Greatly dismayed or horrified.
examples: I was appalled by the lack of cleanliness in the hotel.
She was appalled at the injustices she saw.

words.meaning: A ghost or ghostlike image of a person.
examples: The old castle is said to be haunted by an apparition.
He stared as if he had seen an apparition.

words.meaning: To pacify or placate (someone) by acceding to their demands.
examples: They tried to appease the angry protesters.
The government appeased the rebels by granting them amnesty.

words.meaning: A name or title.
examples: The city earned the appellation 'The Big Apple'.
He was a writer who deserved the appellation of 'genius'.

words.meaning: The act of trying to gain favor with someone by flattery.
examples: His constant apple polishing did not impress the boss.
She was accused of apple polishing to get the promotion.

words.meaning: To divide and allocate.
examples: The court will apportion the blame between the two parties.
The grant was apportioned among several research teams.

words.meaning: Apt in the circumstances or in relation to something.
examples: His remarks were apposite to the topic being discussed.
She always manages to find the most apposite quotation.

words.meaning: To assess the value or quality of.
examples: The jeweler will appraise the diamond ring.
It is important to appraise the situation before making a decision.

words.meaning: Large or important enough to be noticed.
examples: There was an appreciable difference in their ages.
The new policy had an appreciable effect on the economy.

words.meaning: Anxiety or fear that something bad or unpleasant will happen.
examples: He felt a great deal of apprehension before his exam.
There is growing apprehension about the future of the company.

words.meaning: To inform or tell (someone).
examples: Please apprise me of any new developments.
He was apprised of the situation by his lawyer.

words.meaning: Approval or praise.
examples: The new play received widespread approbation from the critics.
He sought the approbation of his peers.

words.meaning: To take (something) for one's own use, typically without the owner's permission.
examples: The government appropriated the land for a new highway.
He was accused of appropriating the company's funds.

words.meaning: Belonging; pertinent.
examples: The garden is appurtenant to the house.
There are various rights appurtenant to the ownership of the land.

words.meaning: Very appropriate to a particular situation.
examples: Her comments were apropos to the discussion.
The film's release, apropos of the current political climate, was timely.

words.meaning: Appropriate or suitable in the circumstances.
examples: That was a very apt description of the situation.
His name is very apt for his profession as a baker.

words.meaning: A natural ability to do something.
examples: She has a great aptitude for learning languages.
The test is designed to measure your aptitude for the job.

words.meaning: Of or containing water, typically as a solvent or medium.
examples: The chemist prepared an aqueous solution of salt.
The human eye contains aqueous humor.

words.meaning: An ornamental design consisting of intertwined flowing lines, originally found in Arabic or Moorish decoration.
examples: The mosque was decorated with intricate arabesques.
The ballet dancer held a perfect arabesque pose.

words.meaning: (of land) used or suitable for growing crops.
examples: The country has a lot of arable land.
Farmers are looking for new arable crops to grow.

words.meaning: A person who settles a dispute or has ultimate authority in a matter.
examples: The court will act as the final arbiter in the dispute.
She is the arbiter of fashion in the office.

words.meaning: Based on random choice or personal whim, rather than any reason or system.
examples: The decision to fire him was completely arbitrary.
The rules seemed arbitrary and unfair.

words.meaning: To (of an independent person or body) reach an authoritative judgment or settlement.
examples: He was called in to arbitrate the dispute between the two companies.
The union and management agreed to arbitrate their differences.

words.meaning: Understood by few; mysterious or secret.
examples: The arcane rules of the game were difficult to understand.
He was an expert in arcane subjects.

words.meaning: Deliberately or affectedly playful and teasing.
examples: She gave him an arch smile.
He made an arch comment about her new hairstyle.

words.meaning: Very old or old-fashioned.
examples: The museum contained archaic artifacts from ancient civilizations.
The company's archaic computer system needs to be updated.

words.meaning: The study of human history and prehistory through the excavation of sites and the analysis of artifacts and other physical remains (also spelled archaeology).
examples: He studied archeology at university.
The discovery was of great interest to archeology.

words.meaning: A very typical example of a certain person or thing.
examples: He is the archetype of a successful businessman.
The hero of the story is a classic archetype.

words.meaning: Enthusiastic or passionate.
examples: She is an ardent supporter of the local football team.
He has an ardent desire to travel the world.

words.meaning: Enthusiasm or passion.
examples: He spoke with great ardor about his love for his country.
The revolutionary's ardor never cooled.

words.meaning: Involving or requiring strenuous effort; difficult and tiring.
examples: It was an arduous journey across the mountains.
The work was arduous, but the rewards were great.

words.meaning: The jargon or slang of a particular group or class.
examples: Criminals have their own argot that is difficult for outsiders to understand.
The book is full of the argot of the theater world.

words.meaning: (of land or a climate) having little or no rain; too dry or barren to support vegetation.
examples: The desert is an arid region with very little rainfall.
The discussion became arid and unproductive.

words.meaning: Complete, utter.
examples: That is arrant nonsense!
He dismissed the rumor as arrant speculation.

words.meaning: An impressive display or range of a particular type of thing.
examples: There was a vast array of food on the table.
The store offers a wide array of products.

words.meaning: To stop or check (a process or development).
examples: The new drug can arrest the spread of the disease.
The government's policies have arrested economic growth.

words.meaning: Striking; eye-catching.
examples: She was a woman of arresting beauty.
The painting was an arresting work of art.

words.meaning: To take or claim (something) for oneself without justification.
examples: The dictator arrogated to himself the power to make all decisions.
She arrogated the leadership role to herself.

words.meaning: Clever or skillful, especially in a crafty or cunning way.
examples: He was an artful negotiator who always got what he wanted.
She gave an artful performance that won over the audience.
